text: test

Eukaryotic Cell: From the greek “Eu” meaning “true,” eukaryotic cells differ from prokaryotic cells in that they contain genetic material within a membrane-bound nucleus and have other membrane-bound organelles with specialized functions.

Endoplasmic Reticulum (Rough): Interconnected membranous structure connected to the nuclear membrane. The rough endoplasmic reticulum is studded with ribosomes and is the site of translation of membrane and secretory proteins.

Ribosome: The site of translation of RNA transcripts into polypeptide chains in protein synthesis. Ribosomes are composed of a large and small subunit each made of catalytic RNA structures.
Peroxisome: A small organelle that degrades fatty acids and amino acids through reactions that produce hydrogen peroxide. Hydrogen peroxide is converted to water and oxygen by the enzyme catalase.

Nuclear Pore: Connections between the inner and outer nuclear membrane that allow access to the nucleus through a series of protein complexes. RNA transcripts pass through these pores to exit the nucleus.
Vesicle: Small transport packages enclosed by lipid-bilayers that contain materials to be transported between different parts of the cell.
Golgi Complex: Stacked membranous structure responsible for sorting and packaging of lipids and proteins before secretion or compartmentalization.

Cytoplasm: A solution of salts, water, and proteins that encompases cellular components within the plasma membrane.


Cytoskeleton: A network of fibrous elements that provides structural support and movement of organelles contained within the cytoplasm of cells. It is composed of microtubules, intermediate filaments, and actin microfilaments.
Matrix: The viscous contents of the cristae in mitochondria. It contains enzymes necessary for oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis and is also home to the mitochondrial DNA.
Intermembrane space: The space between the inner and outer membranes into which protons are pumped from the matrix during electron transport.

Inner membrane: The membrane separating the mitochondrial matrix from the intermembrane space. This membrane contains the protein complexes from the electron transport chain and is the permeable to oxygen, carbon dioxide, and water and is not permeable to ions and small molecules.
Outer membrane: The membrane enclosing the entire organelle from the rest of the cell. It is dotted with structures called porins to allow small proteins to enter into the intermembrane space.
Glycolysis: A 10-step pathway in which one molecule of glucose is converted into two molecules of pyruvate and two molecules of NADH.
The Citric Acid Cycle: An eight step pathway which harvests chemical energy and produces a total of three NADH molecules.
Outer membrane: The membrane enclosing the entire organelle from the rest of the cell. It is dotted with structures called porins to allow small proteins to enter into the intermembrane space.
Intermembrane space: The space between the inner and outer membranes into which protons are pumped from the matrix during electron transport.

Inner membrane: The membrane separating the mitochondrial matrix from the intermembrane space. This membrane contains the protein complexes from the electron transport chain and is the permeable to oxygen, carbon dioxide, and water and is not permeable to ions and small molecules.
Matrix: The viscous contents of the cristae in mitochondria. It contains enzymes necessary for oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis and is also home to the mitochondrial DNA.

Cristae: The crinkled folds of the inner membrane of mitochondria in which the electron transport chain is embedded and ATP synthesis takes place. It appears bunched and folded to maximize surface area.

Complex IV: Also called cytochrome c oxidase, here four electrons are removed from four molecules of cytochrome c and are transferred to O2 oxygen to produce two molecules of water. Simultaneously, eight protons are removed from the mitochondrial matrix, contributing to the proton gradient.

Complex III: Also known as CoQH2-cytochrome c reductase, this complex transfers two electrons from QH2 to two molecules of cytochrome c, a water-soluble intermembrane molecule. Two other electrons are passed across to reduce quinone to quinol. In total, four protons are translocated: two in the reduction of quinone to quinol and two are released from two ubiquinol molecules.

Complex II: Also called succinate dehydrogenase, complex II acts in parallel to complex I to deliver electrons to quinone pool. These electrons come from succinate originally produced in the citric acid cycle which were transferred through FAD. However, no protons are delivered to the intermembrane space by complex II.

Complex I: Also known as NADH-Ubiquinone Oxidoreductase, this is the first site of the electron transport chain. Two electrons are removed from NADH and transferred to ubiquinone (Q), a lipid soluble carrier, which can then diffuse across the membrane as ubiquinol (QH2). This process ultimately moves four H+ protons across the membrane, producing a proton gradient.

ATP Synthase: The site of ATP synthesis at the end of the electrochemical gradient of the electron transport chain. It is composed of a membranous subunit (FO) and lumen-facing subunit (F1). H+ ions pass through the FO subunit to provide energy to the oxidative phosphorylation reaction (ADP + Pi) that takes place at the F1 subunit.
NAD+: A coenzyme involved in metabolism as an oxidizing agent – it accepts electrons from other molecules and becomes reduced.
NADH: A coenzyme involved in metabolism as a reducing  agent – it donates electrons to other molecules and becomes oxidized.

Cyan: Capsule: The outer layer of prokaryotic cells which is gummy or slimy covering that may help bacteria stay together in colonies and/or provide some protection to the cell.

Purple: Cell Wall: A rigid framework of murein, which is a polysaccharide cross-linked by peptide chains.

Yellow: Plasma membrane: A symmetrical two-layer structure that surrounds the cytoplasm and regulates the flow of substances in and out of the cell.

Purple: Ribosomes: The sites of translation of RNA transcripts into polypeptide chains in protein synthesis. Ribosomes are composed of a large and small subunit each made of catalytic RNA structures.

Yellow: Cytoplasm: A solution of salts, water, and proteins that encompases cellular components within the plasma membrane.

Flagella: Long, whip-like protrusions that aid cellular locomotion. The flagellum of a prokaryotic cell does not "beat" but rotates about a "bearing" in the cell wall - resulting in a "corkscrew" motion that drives the cell forwards.

Nucleoid: An irregularly shaped region within the cell of a prokaryote that contains all or most of the genetic material, called genophore. In contrast to the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell, it is not surrounded by a nuclear membrane. The genome of prokaryotic organisms is generally a circular, double-stranded piece of DNA, of which multiple copies may exist at any time.
Plasmid: A small DNA molecule within a cell that is physically separated from a chromosomal DNA and can replicate independently.
α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An enzyme that acts on α-ketoglutarate in an irreversible reaction to give rise to Succinyl-CoA, CO2, and NADH.
Succinyl-CoA: A four-carbon structure (excluding CoA) generated from α-ketoglutarate.
Succinyl-CoA synthetase: An enzyme that generates succinate from succinyl-CoA. This reaction also generates CoA-SH and GTP from GDP and Pi.
Succinate: A four-carbon structure generated from succinyl-CoA.
Succinate dehydrogenase (also called Complex II): An enzyme that uses succinate and ubiquinone in an oxidation reaction that produces FADH2, ubiquinol, and fumarate.
Fumarate: A four-carbon structure formed from succinate.
Fumarase: An enzyme that hydrates fumarate at the double bond to form malate.
Malate: A four-carbon structure that is generated from fumarate by hydration.
Malate dehydrogenase: An enzyme that participates in an oxidation reaction of malate to form oxaloacetate and NADH.
Oxaloacetate: A four-carbon structure generated from malate. Oxaloacetate is used with citrate synthase and acetyl-CoA to restart the citric acid cycle and form citrate.

α-ketoglutarate: A five-carbon structure formed by the removal of a carboxyl group from oxalosuccinate (a six-carbon structure that forms the intermediate between isocitrate and α-ketoglutarate. Decarboxylation of this molecule is by isocitrate dehydrogenase is the key regulatory step of the citric acid cycle.)

Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Enzyme responsible the oxidation of isocitrate to form oxalosuccinate and NADH. Further responsible for decarboxylation of oxalosuccinate to release CO2 and form α-ketoglutarate.
Isocitrate: A six-carbon structure that forms through rehydration of cis-Aconitate. The -OH group is always added on the same side of the molecule as the adjacent carboxyl group.
Aconitase: The enzyme responsible for the rearrangement of citrate into cis-aconitate and isocitrate through dehydration and hydration.
Citrate: The second substrate in the citric acid cycle. This six-carbon structure contains multiple carboxylic acid residues that are functionalized in subsequent steps.
Citrate synthase: The enzyme responsible for transferring the two-carbon acetyl group from acetyl-CoA to the four-carbon oxaloacetate in the formation of the six-carbon molecule citrate.
Acetyl-CoA: The first component in the citric acid cycle. Following decarboxylation, it has lost one carbon in the form of CO2 and now contains two carbon atoms.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase: A component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that participates in decarboxylation of pyruvate to form Acetyl-CoA. This reaction produces one molecule of carbon dioxide and one molecule of NADH.
Pyruvate: The final product of glycolysis and the initial carbon source for the citric acid cycle. Two three-carbon pyruvate molecules are produced from one six-carbon molecule of glucose.
Pyruvate: The final product of glycolysis and the initial carbon source for the citric acid cycle. Two three-carbon pyruvate molecules are produced from one six-carbon molecule of glucose.
Pyruvate kinase: An enzyme that converts phosphoenolpyruvate into pyruvate by removal of a phosphate group. This reaction produces ATP and pyruvate, which then enters the citric acid cycle.
Phosphoenolpyruvate: A pyruvate enol structure that holds a phosphate group to be used in creation of ATP.
Enolase: An enzyme that dehydrates 2-phosphoglycerate to produce phosphoenolpyruvate.
2-Phosphoglycerate: A three-carbon structure with a phosphate group on carbon 2 to reorganize the molecule for pyruvate formation.
Phosphoglycerate mutase: An enzyme that shifts the phosphate functional group from carbon 3 to carbon 2 of phosphoglycerate.
3-Phosphoglycerate: A three-carbon structure with a phosphate group on carbon 3.
Phosphoglycerate kinase: An enzyme that uses the phosphate group on carbon 1 of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to produce ATP from ADP.
1,3-Bisphosphoglycerate: A three-carbon structure with phosphate groups on carbons 1 and 3 that can be used in subsequent reactions to phosphorylate ADP.
Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase: An enzyme that oxidizes glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and adds an additional phosphate group. This reaction produces NADH.

Dihydroxyacetone phosphate: A three-carbon structure that must be converted into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to continue through glycolysis. The phosphate group on carbon 3 prevents free diffusion out of the cell.
Triosephosphate isomerase: An enzyme that converts dihydroxyacetone phosphate into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate.
Glyceraldehyde-3-Phosphate: A three-carbon structure able to continue through glycolysis. The phosphate group on carbon 3 prevents free diffusion of this molecule out of the cell.
Fructose-bisphosphate aldolase: An enzyme that breaks fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate.

Fructose-1,6-Bisphosphate: A six-carbon fructose structure with phosphate groups added to carbons 1 and 6. The presence of two highly charged phosphate groups destabilizes the molecule for the subsequent reaction.
Phosphofructokinase: An enzyme which adds an additional phosphate group to fructose-6-phosphate. This reaction uses ATP and is the key-regulatory  step of glycolysis.
Fructose-6-Phosphate: A six-carbon isomer of glucose-6-phosphate. This  isomer is required for further breakdown in glycolysis, while glucose-6-phosphate is unable to participate.

Phosphoglucose isomerase: An enzyme responsible for the rearrangement of glucose-6-phosphate into fructose-6-phosphate. It is a reversible reaction that is driven by rapid use of fructose-6-phosphate.
Glucose-6-Phosphate: Glucose that has had a phosphate group added to carbon 6. This molecule is unable to exit the cell with the added phosphate.

Hexokinase: An enzyme that adds a phosphate group to carbon 6 of glucose. This reaction allows for continual flow of glucose into the cell by keeping the concentration of non-phosphorylated glucose low. This reaction uses ATP.

Electron Transport Chain: A series of complexes that transfer electrons from electron donors to electron acceptors via redox reactions, and couples this electron transfer with the transfer of protons (H+ ions) across the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Glucose: A simple carbohydrate built on a six-carbon backbone. This is the primary unit of energy derived from food and is the basis for ATP generation through glycolysis, citric acid cycle, and electron transport chain.
Lysosome: Membrane-bound vesicles that contain acidic degradative enzymes. Cellular components are broken down into component parts for recycling in this compartment.
Microtubules: A component of the cytoskeleton, found throughout the cytoplasm. Polymers of tubulin are highly dynamic. Motor proteins move organelles and other cellular along microtubules.
Nucleolus: A portion of the nucleus in which most eukaryotic ribosomal RNA is synthesized and ribosomal subunits are assembled.
Nucleus: A large membrane-bound structure in eukaryotic cells containing DNA. This is also the site of RNA transcription prior to export to the cytoplasm.

Phospholipid Bilayer: A symmetrical two-layer structure that forms the envelope around many cellular structures. Polar phosphate heads point outwards while nonpolar hydrocarbon tails align inwards. This unique polar-nonpolar-polar layering prevents entry of large complex molecules into the cell.

Extracellular Matrix: An insoluble network of fibrous proteins, polysaccharides, and other proteins that provide structural support on the exterior of the cell surface. It is also thought to play a role in biochemical signaling between cells.

Endoplasmic Reticulum (Smooth): Interconnected membranous structure connected to the nuclear membrane. The smooth endoplasmic reticulum has no ribosomes but is contiguous with the rough endoplasmic reticulum and is a site of lipid synthesis.
Centrosome: A protein complex that is the organizing center of microtubules that also regulates phases of the cell cycle.
Golgi Complex: Stacked membranous structure responsible for sorting and packaging of lipids and proteins before secretion or compartmentalization.

Mitochondrion: An organelle with two phospholipid bilayers that contains machinery necessary for oxidative phosphorylation and therefore the site of ATP synthesis. Containing its own genome, mitochondria are thought to have originated as an independent organism.

Prokaryotic Cell: From the greek “pro” meaning “before” and “karyon” meaning “nut or kernel,” prokaryotic cells differ from eukaryotic cells in that they do not contain a membrane-bound nucleus or have other membrane-bound organelles with specialized functions. The endosymbiotic theory states that mitochondria originated from prokaryotes that were taken inside another cell as an endosymbiont around 1.5 billion years ago.

ATP Synthase: The site of ATP synthesis at the end of the electrochemical gradient of the electron transport chain. It is composed of a membranous subunit (FO) and lumen-facing subunit (F1). H+ ions pass through the FO subunit to provide energy to the oxidative phosphorylation reaction (ADP + Pi) that takes place at the F1 subunit.

Example reply!

Panel 1) Title card that reads:

Calvin and Hobbes by Watterson
Panel 2) Hobbes is under the covers smiling and appears to be getting up. Meanwhile, Calvin is already up and hovering mid-air over the bed.
Panel 3) Calvin is eating a bowl of cereal while Hobbes munches on a piece of toast. Both of them are looking at what appears to be the funny pages of a newspaper. Hobbes looks a bit perplexed.
Panel 4) Hobbes and Calvin race out the door with huge smiles on their faces.

Panel 5) Calvin stands in front of a tree trunk holding onto a toy gun. His tongue is sticking out while his face makes a look that shows concentration. Meanwhile, Hobbes is behind the same tree but opposite the side Hobbes is looking also holding a toy gun.
Panel 6) Calvin hangs off a branch upside down while holding onto his lips and making a funny face. Meanwhile, Hobbes is taking a photograph of Calvin making a funny face.

Panel 7) Calvin and Hobbes are both waist-deep into a hole. Hobbes is holding on to what appers to be a shovel while wiping off his brow. Calvin meanwhile is wearing a typical explorer's hat while intently reading a book titled "DINOSAURS"

Panel 8) Calvin and Hobbes are in a green pool with black polka dots. Hobbes is wearing an orange bathing suit and laughing as he holds up a blue bathing suit high above his friend while pointing at him. Meanwhile a naked Calvin is angrily reaching up to try and get his bathing suit back.
Panel 9) Hobbes is tilting a rock off the ground while Calvin stares underneath. Both are making disgusted faces.

Panel 10) Calvin and Hobbes are wearing masks and running towards the right side of the panel. Hobbes is holding on to a small triangular purple flag while Calvin is ahead of him holding a volleyball.
Panel 11) Calvin and Hobbes lay on their backs on the grass. Both are pointing upwards towards the sky and Calvin appears to be saying something.

Part 12) Calvin and Hobbes appear to be having a scuffle. The tiger is upside down holding on to Calvin as they tumble with strained faces. Around them, small colorful stars, some clouds, a small planet, and a small crescent moon surround their active, playful fight.

Panel 13) We see Hobbes and Calvin hiding behind a tree. Hobbes is holding on to what appears to be a light blue water balloon. Calvin has just chucked his balloon which hits a person in the left part of the frame right on the head!
Panel 14) We see Calvin's upper body as he climbs a tree while above him we see the lower half of Hobbes climbing up as well.
Panel 15) Calvin and Hobbes stand patiently waiting at their sale stand which reads "Suicide Drink 25c". On their stand sits a pitcher filled with what appears to be brown liquid or sludge.
Panel 16) All we see is the lower half of Calvin's body and Hobbes' body as they dash off towards the left of the panel.

Panel 17) The background is a gradient light purple to light pink. Hobbes is holding a pair of binoculars looking through them at the crescent moon off in the distance. Calvin is looking at Hoobes with his hand reaching out for the binoculars.
Panel 18) The background is a deep purple. Hobbes appears to be looking at something in his paws. Calvin runs around trying to catch one of the four fireflies that seem to be flying around them.

Panel 19) We see Calvin being hoisted off from outside, as it appears to be dark out, by his collar. The bottom half of his mother is shown as she "pulls him inside." In her other hand, a plushy teddy tiger hangs limp. Calvin appers to be screaming in protest.

Panel 20) We see Calvin and Hobbes under the covers in bed. Calvin looks towards his right at Hobbes while talking. Hobbes faces forward looking at the reader. 

Calvin: "Summer days are supposed to be longer. But they sure seem short to me."

Hobbes: "I'll say. We didn't get to do half our itinerary."

text: I found it puzzling that there are 15 stars on the flags in the centre of the painting, 17 on the left and only 9 on the right hand side. US flag never had that amount of stars, and during Perry's misson counted 31 stars.

stark contrast between the flowing, light coloured waves and the stark black bulk of the ship's hull. showing how the boats cut forced nature aside, much like Commodore Perry brushing aside any Japan's desire to maintain self-seclusion through his use of gunboat diplomacy.
the details of the drawings are astonishing
what does this thing represents ? This artwork is very recise and very realistic so but this one thing I can't figure what this is...
There is a cinematic quality to the print as we see one ship recede into distance.  Or does this show total number of ships in the Perry mission?
this boat must be a japanese boat ? It seems to be here to render the size of th steam boat...they are very huge compared to this one !
Great detailed

The technical detail in this screen is very far beyond the detail I have seen in the other depictions of the American ships. It is evident that the artist had a long time to look at the ships and figure out the proportions and placement of everything. It's also impressive to see just how well armed the Perry Expedition was. The array of cannons on this ship is really impressive and I can understand the fear that just looking at this ship would inspire.
In this photo, the American Flag of Star-Spangled Banners looks right. The previous black ship pictures missed the starts.
Staying alive
There are no monsters. This is a sign of better relationships between Japan and America

History aside - as for style, the only thing that makes these ships look Westerners compared to Japanese junks is - confusion.

Japanese found grace in the blackness and equilibrium in the wood-rope net of the ships.
I have been surprised about the way these ships are depicted - we can see every tiny detail in the pictures
People are depicted as disciplined crew members which shows The Japanise respect towards the Americans

The attention to detail is amazing in all of this. I love old ships and the ropes and rigging always seemed gorgeous and complicated. The artwork here acknowledges the complexity of the rigging in a very simple, natural way. I'm impressed.

As an illustrator, I'm realy impresssed by thre use of the paper and transparency to give the impression of a cloudy day in those painting (helped by the lack of shadows). The precise way everything is portrayed, almost technical and simple mood given by that cloudy day make me feel like this scene is more part of what will become "normal" to Japanese.
this drawing is very detailed, makes it very informative.
Artist seems to show scale of the drawing by placing crew members at various points.
In this image, several sailors are placed through the ship in order to emphasise the scale of the vessel

Very accurate and detailed image of complicated and unusual constructions, but... here we can see some perspective failures. Maybe an artist is trying to use some methods of western painters (he might see some pictures during Perry's visit)/ Or the whole thing is too complicated to present it in the usual way.
I am amazed at the attention to detail of Japanese artists. Their realism is extraordinary.
As a sailor, I couldnot but notice the exact rendition of the rigging.
Just the attention to detail on  the craftsmanship of the American warships is astounding and provides such a realistic and heavily detailed image.
The sailor's gesture is so accurate and realistic that it is amazingly impressive.
The sketches are not only technical but beautiful as we can feel the wind blowing into the American flag as it float with such elegance.
I love how the Japanese painting are always so detailed that they even included the American flags on each and every ship.
no more flying sailors!

People in uniform working. United to the sea view, this shows Japanese minded realistic pictures with details shown in context. Link to Whitehead organism philosophy and the Japanese "one (i.e. me) in the whole" worldview.

As Musashi said (implied) in Dokkodo, the value of things is to be used by humans. If you paint ships, you paint sailors.

Nothing that fellow students haven't commented yet, but this is a truly impressive piece of art, and I believe it reflects so much of the Japanese character. They truly are a detail-focused, observant people, with a penchant for conveying what they saw in a most refined, sophisticated way.

The depiction of human figures is not as detailed as the technological objetcs, but it serves as a scale to compare the size of the steamships and the size and amount of people that could be carried.

Also the figures depict some of the actions required for maintainance and operation of the stemships, such as mounting, cleaning, releasing and arranging of ropes and sails (as in this corner of the image)
The attention to detail is very interesting. Even on the top we can see people working and the ropes clearly defined. There is a big analytical work behind this painting.

The depictions of sea waves are the most naturallistic representation in the scenes.

I think this is due to the long historic connection for japanese culture to the sea and their developed observation to natural elements; japanese artists use a combination of various lines to depict subtle movement and ripples, as well as the blue nuances of light blue colour and white to create deepness and freshness in a style that is recognizable throughout the entire history of japanese art since the ancient times.
What is this box? It stands out from the black of the ship so strongly.
With how bright and vivid the American flags are compared to everything else, i'd say that they center of attention.
Great attention to detail, to even include stars on the smallest flags here.
No more monsters on the ship, maybe to convey better relations better Japan and America?
A lot of detail going into the ships, as far as showing people up on the sails with their blue sailor outfits and hats.
The ships are no longer being demonized, showing a change in the attitudes of the Japanese peoples towards the Americans.
Wondering what this is (the dark form behind the blue man). Looks to me like it has a head, arms and body, but proportionately it seems too large to be a human figure. Thoughts anyone?
Look at the very detailed painting, no only the smoke, but also the tiny crew climbing all over the parts of the ship
What flag is this, it looks like the 'stars' without the stipes
The overall colour scheme is very pale and insipid, setting a dismal, bleak mood to the event.
So much black smoke gives me the impression of something huge, of power, in this case.
A more realistc and less biased depiction of the americans.
No more demonic faces on the vessels. That's another hint that this was made a few years later!
Is a very realisitic scene. Japanese have time to know americans better. Americans aren't a menace.

The depiction emphasize the impression that this big quantity of smoke produced by the ships caused in the observers, trying to explain the enormous power of this warships and the frightening feeling of risk for the population.

The smoke cloud could represent the most emotionally charged element of the scene. This great dark area outside the steamships could represent the might and danger that the Americans themselves brought to Japan in the form of technology and weaponery.

The black smoky clouds posses emotional strenght as a symbol also in later japanese artwork such as the Raijin & Fuujin folding screen by Tawaraya Soutatsu.
Is this the realistic portrayal of the American Flag at this time?

Look at these people here. Why are they there? Why does the illustrator include them? Discuss the depiction of humans in this image. Consider their color, their size, the extent to which they are "realistic," and other factors.

Consider the depiction of the natural environment in which the ships appear. How does the illustrator represent the sky? the sea? flora and fauna? What is the relationship between the ships and the natural world? Why does the illustrator make the choices he does in depicting the natural world, and what message is he trying to convey through these choices?

text: Seems to be much more detail of the water than any background for the ships, which seem to emerge out of thin air, coming from nowhere
Consider and discuss the depiction of flags throughout the image.
Incredible detail work
The amount of detail that went into the drawings indicates that from the moment the ships arrived, artists made sure that engineers were able to reproduce the ships. Or at least the intention
The figures are very tall and thin, maybe to emphasize the american complexion, if we compare with the thickness of a robe left above in the image with almost the same thickness as one of his legs.
Here we can see a lookout sailor managing his telescope to observe the seashore showing how accurate are the depictions
wonderful depiction of watersea, so realistic and delicate
It is remarkable the skill of japanese painters that recreate with great accuracy  the structural framework of masts, ropes, folded sails...
The representation of sea and sky is minimal, perhaps, not to distract viewers, as if saying that they are a mere background, and the focus is on ships only.

text: I think one of the main points about these little sailing figures is scale and number. They are dressed identical, uniform infact, so they aren't individually special people. The size of these ships was a surprise for Japan, and showing the people on them would give the viewer who never saw them themselves a reference point to the size of the ships, and possibly how many could man/contain them.

text: I think it's interesting that, alongside quite good attention to detail, the volume and opacity of the smoke is really overstated. I feel this could be evidence of how surprising such large naval guns were to the japanese artist - they saw bigger clouds than they expected, and subconsciously exaggerated them.

text: Unlike earlier work this depiction lacks the demonic figurheads and other embellishments. The rigging and mastwork is realistically rendered (I like the maritime skills to know if it is accurate). Some details have good consistency, steam billows and multiple flags being wind swept in the same direction, Hollywood sometimes struggles to get those things correct today

text: The depictions of the paddlewheels seem to change pretty significantly from the initial trip of Perry to this screen. The earlier paddlewheels are very sytlized and impressionistic. These paddlewheels are much more detailed, and you can almost see the artist's mental deconstruction and re-engineering of the them.

text:
It seems to be a picture of the American Black ships leaving. Whether it's their first or second visit is unclear. 

What's interesting is the fact that the American flag is depicted correctly here,in contrast to many other visuals/sketches.

text: 40 men -as crew al least- are shown in the ship. I am sure that the artist knows to sail. He depicted mainly all the functions in a ship by seamen. So, this is a technical drawing -very beautiful and artistically done. And to not confusing the bout’s structure he didn’t depict the sky but he did the wind and sea.

text: The blandness of the weather seems deliberate. The pale sky and the barely there blue ocean force the viewer to focus on the ships. The realistic depiction of the ships in the left two panels gives a sense of size, depth and motion of the ships. The third panel (which I agree is probably done by a diff. artist) is a flat rendering but with great detail given to all the ships staff, rigging, masts, etc... To me all these things make me feel that this scroll was probably used for study by scholars and Feudal leaders.

text: Looking through, it is evident that the ships were of greater importance to the artist than the people manning them. That is why there is such minute detail in even the masts and the way the water moves under the boat and its equipment.

text: I was surprised by the amount of detail; however, in order to display the most accurate information about the ships and personnel, it was necessary to be detailed. These pictures could be used as references for actual reproduction. The perspective used for the side wheel seems a little "off," but in this way the artist could show more of the important structural detail. The details which were of lesser inportance to the Japanese were not so accurate, as in the case of the American flag.

text: Calm weather all around but for me this feels a bit intimidating owing to the fact that everything is bland. Even the skies, beautiful as they were during a gorgeous Japanese day, is devoid of any clouds or even the regular blue you usually see. Makes the painting seem lifeless but the animation provided by the ships contrasts with the underlying 'quietness' of the images.

text: The depictions appear more objective now that communication and some understanding between the two contingents have taken place.  Gone are the menacing demonic faces on the bow and stern, the portrayal of evil or threat.  These are impressive ships, yes, but just naval ships with naval staff doing their work.  The detail in illustrating the ropes, masts, those openings on the sides of the ships, the smaller boats, the billowing smoke, and everything really is impressive.  I've enjoyed looking at this row of images in detail.  I notice a couple of seemingly special bright red rowing boats - I wonder why they are red, are they for high ranking officers only?  The lines in the ocean waves and charcoal smoke makes me think how oriental in style it is.  Wonderful illustration.

text: All the American boats show lots of industry, many sailors at work. But the scale isn't quite right, so there's a sense that they've been added to emphasize the size of these ships, especially when compared to Japanese ships. It must be the equivalent of an aircraft carrier appearing in Boston Harbor: fascinating, enormous, filled with life, and lots of detail.

text: The detail on the paddle-wheel is incredible. I think this is a great example of not only the Japanese curiosity about these ships, but also their artistic attention to detail. Not only is the wheel accurate, it is asthetically pleasing.

text: It's artistic and beautifully drawn but it also feels as a technical study - there is not a missing cable or wire - to understand how it is made, what it does and for the Japanese to build their own... The representation shows technical as well as esthetical admiration but also desire to own the same...

text:
They couldn't help throwing in a "perfect" profile shot, could they?

This illustration feels much more of a "study" than the others, and also a lot less "free", artistically. The ship is perfectly framed, in near perfect profile, and as far as the ship itself is concerned, there's little sign of "bahaviour".

text:
Is this flag innaccurate, or merely a flag I was no able to find? I attempted to find the flag by searching US Naval flags and other versions of the US flag at the time of his voyage, but was unable to find it.

It seems odd to me because it's so consistently reproduced with this look, and this particular patterning of the stars seems overly complicated for a "misrepresentation" by a foreigner who couldn't accurately reproduce the pattern. Indeed, all patterns I found at this time are simply than this one.

text: The American flag is displayed everywhere, on every boat. Its so prominent against the black ships, but also the sea and sky. They must have really stood out to the artists, either for their colour or for their symbolism of who and what these ships represented.

text: As an English student I was surprised to see this unusual arrangement of the stars on the American Flag on what seems to be a well observed and deatiled painting. I was even more surpised to find that many variations were used over time (and not necessarily because of new States joing the Union). The screen uses this arrangement on others ships, is it likely to be correct? If not why not? the artist has clearly observed the fleet.

text: The ships are depicted in great detail, they are shown really realistically, and you can also see ships in depth as well as the patterns of the waves formed in the sea around them. But there are no drawings of birds or fish or mammals that should normally show on a realistic drawing. Thus, these drawings show up really detailed and realistic, but they are not made to fill in the curiosity of Japanese; they seem to be made to carefully describe the technological gap they had from Americans at the time when Commodore Perry showed up in Japan. So this looks like an instructive collection of American ships in an attempt to remember them so that they can build their own.

text: The American Flags look like accurate. I am very curious about the depiction of them. As misterspock1 mentioned, they have to have 31 stars (California was the newest state at that time) and 13 stripes even this flag has 14 stripes. The Japanese painters would make them (at least one depiction of a flag) if they knew the history of the “Stars and Stripes”.

text: The men are dwarfed by the ship. Perhaps this helps to illustrate the technological might wielded by what were seen as otherwise very human (described by the Japanese in ways indicating they were seen as kind, foolish, jovial, etc). The ships are more a part of the landscape, forces of natural power, than they are connected with humanity and its tools.

text:
Here I was struck by the variation in U.S. flags as depicted on these panels of the screen. 4 flags have a large star in the upper corner and a group of smaller stars, and one flag has uniformly sized stars. Did Perry fly different versions of the U.S. flag or are these just different interpretations of the same flag by the Japanese? The 31-star flag became the official U.S. flag on July 4, 1851, a star having been added to mark the statehood of California (Sept 9, 1850). This 31-star flag was the flag flown for 7 years (1851-1858), so it was the flag Perry sailed under.

 

Japanese images of American flags on the screen show fewer stars, eg., 9 stars, or 16 plus one big star (1), 14 plus one big star (2). There are usually 14 or 13 stripes (a white one added on the bottom), so the observation of stripes was close to accurate. Could the same be true of the number of stars? Stars are harder to depict and fit into a small space. But do the four flags depicted with one big star in the upper corner in addition to the array of small ones reflect a real flag used by the fleet?

 

There was a 31-star American flag that had a big white star, but in the middle of a squarish field of 30 smaller ones. The big star represented the recently added state of California. The basic pattern of this flag is the Trumbull Flag, used by the Navy during the War of Independence and from around 1778 to 1880. The original Trumbull pattern was thirteen stars for the original colonies, one star larger and in the middle, seen in Revolutionary War paintings by John Trumbull. This original 13-star pattern is also seen in paintings of American ships of the early and mid-19th century, flying from the mast and flagstaffs.

 

But the flags on the screen do not depict the big star as being in the middle. So, the Japanese image could be an interpretation of the 1853 Commodore Perry flag, which has 31 stars: a square 5x5 grid with a leftmost column of 6, to make up 31. The topmost star on the leftmost column, by standing above the other stars at the top may have seemed unusually prominent, especially rippling in the wind, and thus depicted as larger than the rest. The usual 31-star flag of the time was also arranged in a way that could have had the effect of making the stars at either end of the topmost row seem unusually prominent because they were surrounded by more blue.

 

However, the flags depicted on the Todai screen with one big star have close to 13 smaller ones, and the same pattern of stars and blue space, which leads me to wonder if the Japanese artist is perhaps depicting a variant original Trumbull pattern flag used by the Navy in Perry’s time. The ships are depicted so meticulously that this seems possible. Also, Trumbull flags were often flown from the stern, and this is the case with the four flags here.

text:
Here I was struck by the variation in U.S. flags as depicted on these panels of the screen. 4 flags have a large star in the upper corner and a group of smaller stars, and one flag has uniformly sized stars. Did Perry fly different versions of the U.S. flag or are these just different interpretations of the same flag by the Japanese? The 31-star flag became the official U.S. flag on July 4, 1851, a star having been added to mark the statehood of California (Sept 9, 1850). This 31-star flag was the flag flown for 7 years (1851-1858), so it was the flag Perry sailed under.

 

Japanese images of American flags on the screen show fewer stars, eg., 9 stars, or 16 plus one big star (1), 14 plus one big star (2). There are usually 14 or 13 stripes (a white one added on the bottom), so the observation of stripes was close to accurate. Could the same be true of the number of stars? Stars are harder to depict and fit into a small space. But do the four flags depicted with one big star in the upper corner in addition to the array of small ones reflect a real flag used by the fleet?

 

There was a 31-star American flag that had a big white star, but in the middle of a squarish field of 30 smaller ones. The big star represented the recently added state of California. The basic pattern of this flag is the Trumbull Flag, used by the Navy during the War of Independence and from around 1778 to 1880. The original Trumbull pattern was thirteen stars for the original colonies, one star larger and in the middle, seen in Revolutionary War paintings by John Trumbull. This original 13-star pattern is also seen in paintings of American ships of the early and mid-19th century, flying from the mast and flagstaffs.

 

But the flags on the screen do not depict the big star as being in the middle. So, the Japanese image could be an interpretation of the 1853 Commodore Perry flag, which has 31 stars: a square 5x5 grid with a leftmost column of 6, to make up 31. The topmost star on the leftmost column, by standing above the other stars at the top may have seemed unusually prominent, especially rippling in the wind, and thus depicted as larger than the rest. The usual 31-star flag of the time was also arranged in a way that could have had the effect of making the stars at either end of the topmost row seem unusually prominent because they were surrounded by more blue.

 

However, the flags depicted on the Todai screen with one big star have close to 13 smaller ones, and the same pattern of stars and blue space, which leads me to wonder if the Japanese artist is perhaps depicting a variant original Trumbull pattern flag used by the Navy in Perry’s time. The ships are depicted so meticulously that this seems possible. Also, Trumbull flags were often flown from the stern, and this is the case with the four flags here.

text: The men are dwarfed by the ship. Perhaps this helps to illustrate the technological might wielded by what were seen as otherwise very human (described by the Japanese in ways indicating they were seen as kind, foolish, jovial, etc). The ships are more a part of the landscape, forces of natural power, than they are connected with humanity and its tools.

text: By this point the Japanese are depicting the American ships with more realistic features rather than the fanciful, demonic imagery of the earlier representations. In some ways it's a more dignified view of the fleet, perhaps reflecting the state of relations between Japan and America at the time of the creation of this scroll.

text: Since the Japanese had been forbidden from building large ships for so long, I think it would have been interesting and maybe fearful for them to see men up at this great height, so they've taken the time to draw them in in detail.

text: The American Flags look like accurate. I am very curious about the depiction of them. As misterspock1 mentioned, they have to have 31 stars (California was the newest state at that time) and 13 stripes even this flag has 14 stripes. The Japanese painters would make them (at least one depiction of a flag) if they knew the history of the “Stars and Stripes”.

text: Seeing the guns firing is really interesting, because as we heard in the video, the Japanese were likely not familiar with the practice of gun salutes.  It's surprising that Perry would fire at all, with the possibility that the shots could be interpreted as attack.

text: The ships are depicted in great detail, they are shown really realistically, and you can also see ships in depth as well as the patterns of the waves formed in the sea around them. But there are no drawings of birds or fish or mammals that should normally show on a realistic drawing. Thus, these drawings show up really detailed and realistic, but they are not made to fill in the curiosity of Japanese; they seem to be made to carefully describe the technological gap they had from Americans at the time when Commodore Perry showed up in Japan. So this looks like an instructive collection of American ships in an attempt to remember them so that they can build their own.

text: As an English student I was surprised to see this unusual arrangement of the stars on the American Flag on what seems to be a well observed and deatiled painting. I was even more surpised to find that many variations were used over time (and not necessarily because of new States joing the Union). The screen uses this arrangement on others ships, is it likely to be correct? If not why not? the artist has clearly observed the fleet.

text:
They couldn't help throwing in a "perfect" profile shot, could they?

This illustration feels much more of a "study" than the others, and also a lot less "free", artistically. The ship is perfectly framed, in near perfect profile, and as far as the ship itself is concerned, there's little sign of "bahaviour".

text:
Is this flag innaccurate, or merely a flag I was no able to find? I attempted to find the flag by searching US Naval flags and other versions of the US flag at the time of his voyage, but was unable to find it.

It seems odd to me because it's so consistently reproduced with this look, and this particular patterning of the stars seems overly complicated for a "misrepresentation" by a foreigner who couldn't accurately reproduce the pattern. Indeed, all patterns I found at this time are simply than this one.

text: This drawing represents the pollution, the contamination caused by US Navy when they came in contact with the Japanese. This contact, for the Japanese, can also be seen as an act of contamination, as they "contaminated" the foreign culture with their costume and may also have altered traditions

text: The artist tries to keep background colors and landscape as neutral as possible, in order to emphasize the details of the blackships. The scene develops in a calmed way, with the effect of highlighting the size and power of the black ships vs. the japanese boats and make the spectator to go closer on details.

text: The depiction of the American fleet is interesting in that the ships are highly detailed, particularly the ropework, while the overall fleet is rendered in a manner to suggest that the Squadron made a significant physical impact upon the Japanese.
